Updated November     pm



 local photographer and filmmaker Jackie Renn said PERIOD

Renn grew up during the Vietnam War PERIOD It was then that she formed the opinion she still holds today War is not always the answer and people have the right to think that way PERIOD Her message is one of freedom of choiceeveryone should have a chance for their voice to be heard and their right to do so protected PERIOD

Renns project What Is Conscience will premiere at the Henry Art Gallery tonight at  p.m PERIOD The event combines elements of her previous photographic works Portraits of Conscience a series of photographs detailing various protests in the Seattle area and Voices of Conscience a short film showcasing conscientious objectors of war and their stories PERIOD

The event will also include a guest panel featuring Pat Gallagher of the ACLU Gerry Condon President of the Greater Seattle Veterans for Peace and Larry Ebersole of Amnesty International Washington State PERIOD Admission is free of charge PERIOD

Renns project centers around the topic of conscientious objectors individuals who oppose the war and thus see military service as a conflict of interest PERIOD It carries an official status and Renns work aims to show the injustice these individuals have received over the years while at the same time promoting the finer points of the First Amendment which guarantees freedom of religion press speech and the right to peaceably assemble PERIOD

 Renn said PERIOD 

Renn explained that conscientious objectors in other countries such as Germany are often assigned to a civil service position instead of contributing to the war effort PERIOD

 she said PERIOD

Renn also stated that this type of civil service is a movement gaining steam here in the United States PERIOD

 she said citing the success those kinds of programs have seen in other countries PERIOD

The history of conscientious objectors in the United States is often negatively associated PERIOD The status has become a stigma and there are several cases of conscientious objectors being treated unjustly PERIOD Renn believes such injustice is a violation of First Amendment rights and she aims to show that in her work PERIOD

 she said PERIOD The past ten years have afforded another historical look at conscientious objectors with the Iraq War PERIOD

 she said PERIOD 

Renns project supports the conscientious objectors who are persecuted for their views and by association she said their First Amendment rights PERIOD

 she said PERIOD 

 she said bringing to mind the WTO protests held here in Seattle a decade ago PERIOD

She also stressed the importance of the role students have in influencing political change PERIOD

 she said PERIOD 

The Henry Art Gallery provides a supportive venue for Renns cause PERIOD

 she said PERIOD Renn cited the gallerys Open Floor program as being ideal for her project PERIOD The program is open to all forms of art presentation which is why Renn felt comfortable with the venue PERIOD

 she said in reference to the crowds a college venue could potentially draw PERIOD

Betsey Brock associate director of communications at the Henry elaborated on the nature of the Open

Floor program PERIOD

 she said PERIOD

Renns project for example was proposed to Open Floor earlier in

the year and is being showcased now PERIOD



said Brock PERIOD

As for a uniting goal Renn would like to achieve with the presentation



Its a message she hopes everyone can get behind PERIOD

Reach reporter Cameron Ellis at weekenderdailyuw.com PERIOD

Amid a sea of rainbow flags festive clothing and outrageous floats spectators at Seattles Pride Festival celebrated the gay lesbian bisexual and transgender community on Sunday PERIOD

The June  event was part of a citywide Pride weekend which included a Queerfest in Capitol Hill and a  political march on Saturday PERIOD

The parade procession which began at Columbia Street and ended at Seattle Center featured floats ranging from a Seattle Transit Bus with the route reading  to a Bear Bath and Beyond foam party float PERIOD  is a reference to an outwardly masculine subculture in the gay community PERIOD

Aids Clinical Trial Unit ACTU a UW organization participated in Sundays parade PERIOD

Group member Megan Fisher said the group hoped to raise awareness by handing out buttons and fliers PERIOD

 she said PERIOD

The Pride Festival began in  and was originally located in Capitol Hill the heart of Seattles gay community PERIOD Last year the event was moved to Seattle Center and left Seattle  in debt due to higher expenses according to www.pridedepot.com

Seattle City Council members Tom Rasmussen and Sally Clark were presented with and later approved a largescale Pride project this year pairing the parade and festival and creating joint advertising in order to curb costs PERIOD

Jarid Scheurer a participant at both the Capitol Hill and Seattle Center parades appreciates the move PERIOD

 Scheurer said PERIOD 

Performers at the Fisher Pavilion included female dance singerssongwriters Inaya Day and Reina as well as DJs Brian Pfeifer and Wasabi PERIOD The Seattle Mens and Womens Choruses also took to the stage singing songs about religion and the incorporation of the gay community PERIOD

Nonprofit organizations and corporate sponsors such as Macys and Naked Juice set up booths and games PERIOD

One such group the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence created a large game of Twister on the lawn next to Fisher Pavilion PERIOD Members of the group are described as twenty-first century nuns for gay and lesbian communities PERIOD

A 6foot3inch group member by the name of Sister Lotus adorned in a bright purple veil white makeup and a Japaneseinspired ensemble has traveled to Pride events all around the country PERIOD

 Sister Lotus said PERIOD 

According to gaylife.com cities across the U.S PERIOD sponsor festivities each June to honor the  Stonewall riots in New York  the first protests against gay discrimination and violence PERIOD

Scheurer said the diversity and number of people at the festival impress him each year PERIOD

 Scheurer said PERIOD
